Name: readlink
Warning: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results.  Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL. (CWE-362, CWE-20)
Suggestion: Reconsider approach

Name: readlink
Warning: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results.  Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL. (CWE-362, CWE-20)
Suggestion: Reconsider approach

Name: access
Warning: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition (CWE-362/CWE-367!)
Suggestion: Set up the correct permissions (e.g., using setuid()) and try to open the file directly

Name: sprintf
Warning: Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120)
Suggestion: Use sprintf_s, snprintf, or vsnprintf

Name: printf
Warning: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134)
Suggestion: Use a constant for the format specification

Name: mktemp
Warning: Temporary file race condition (CWE-377)

Name: execvp

Suggestion: try using a library call that implements the same functionality if available

Name: mkstemp
Warning: Potential for temporary file vulnerability in some circumstances.  Some older Unix-like systems create temp files with permission to write by all by default, so be sure to set the umask to override this. Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library (CWE-377)

Name: vfork
Warning: On some old systems, vfork() permits race conditions, and it's very difficult to use correctly (CWE-362)
Suggestion: Use fork() instead
